title: Establishment and long-term culture of mouse mammary stem cell organoids and breast tumor organoids
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Isolation of mouse mammary epithelial cells
Timing: 3–4 h
Euthanize mice according to the protocol approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of Albert Einstein College of Medicine.
Tissue digestion
For Mammary fat pad digestion
Harvest the #2, 3 & 4 mammary fat pads and wash them in a sterile 15 mL conical tube with 10 mL ice-cold PBS. Multiple mice can be combined for large preparation.
Transfer glands to a petri dish and mince them into ∼1 mm3 pieces using sterile blade.
Transfer the minced glands to a new 15 mL tube by resuspending them with 5 mL of Gland Digestion Buffer I (see section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’) per mouse.
Place the digestion mixture on a nutator in a 37°C incubator for 1.5 - 2 h.
For Tumor digestion
Harvest the tumor (∼1 cm in diameter) and wash with 10 mL ice-cold PBS in a 15 mL tube.
Mince the tumor into ∼ 1 mm3 pieces using a sterile blade.
Transfer the minced tumor fragments to a new 15 mL tube by resuspending them with 5 mL Tumor Digestion Buffer I (see section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’).
Place the digestion mixture on a nutator in a 37°C incubator for 2 h.
After digestion is complete, add 5 mL PBS to each 15 mL tube with digested tissue to reduce the viscosity of the digested tissue mixture.
Pipette the tissue mixture up and down for 20 times.
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 5 min at 4°C–8°C.
Carefully aspirate the supernatant (fatty top layer and liquid layer). Do not disturb the cell pellet.
Red blood cell (RBC) lysis.

For mammary epithelial cell isolation: this step is optional. If yield is important, perform red blood cell lysis. For each mouse, add 1 mL RBC lysis, resuspend cell pellet, and place tube on ice for 1 min. After 1 min, pipet the cell mixture up and down gently for 5–6 times, add 10 mL PBS to the tube and spin down at 500 × g for 5 min. If yield is not an issue (like in large preps), resuspend the pellet with 10 mL PBS by pipetting, pulse spin at 1,000 × g for 1 min. remove the supernatant containing red blood cells.
For tumor organoid cell isolation: perform RBC lysis as above.
Resuspend cell pellets in 1 mL 0.05% trypsin-EDTA, place the tube at 37°C for 5 min, mixing occasionally by shaking.
After 5 min, pipet the cell mixture to dissociate clumps.
Add 10 mL basic medium II (see section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’) to stop the digestion and centrifuge at 700 × g for 5 min. Remove the supernatant.
Resuspend cell pellets with 1 mL Digestion Buffer II (see section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’) by pipetting and incubate for 5 min at 37°C with occasional mixing by shaking.
After 5 min, pipet the cell mixture to dissociate clumps.
To stop the digestion, add 10 mL PBS and centrifuge at 700 × g for 5 min. Remove the supernatant.
Resuspend with 3 mL Suspension Buffer (see section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’).
Note: EDTA helps quench dispase and prevent aggregation.
Filter through 40 μm cell strainers to get single cells (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).

Cell counting:
Mix 0.1 mL cell suspension with 0.1 mL 0.4% trypan blue. The volume of cell suspension can be reduced to 20 μl if needed.

Count the live cell number by Hemocytometer. Live cells will not take up trypan blue.
Critical: All spins should be done in the refrigerated centrifuge at 4°C–8°C.
Establishing MaSC/tumor organoids from freshly isolated cells
Timing: 1 week
Before proceeding with the plating, wash cells with organoid culture medium.
Pellet down the cell suspension by centrifuging the tube at 700 × g for 5 min.
Resuspend the pellet
Freshly prepare the ice-cold organoid culture medium with 5% Matrigel (see section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’; For tumor organoid and normal basal stem cell organoid culture, use MaSC/tumor organoid culture medium I; For luminal progenitor organoid culture, use MaSC organoid culture medium II)
Resuspend the cell pellet in ice-cold organoid culture medium (containing 5% Matrigel, see section ‘Materials and Equipment’) at a final concentration of 150,000 cells per 1 mL of organoid culture medium. For one well of poly-HEMA coated 6-well plates (see section ‘before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]’), seed 300,000 cells with 2 mL culture medium.
Put the plate in the humidified incubator at 37°C with 5% CO2 for organoid culture.
Replace the medium every 3 days.
Check the organoid growth under a light microscope. After 4–6 days, organoids (> 100 μm in diameter) should form.
Critical: All spins should be done in the refrigerated centrifuge at 4°C–8°C.
Passaging MaSC/tumor organoid culture
Timing: 1 week or experiment dependent
Organoids can be passaged once reaching 100–200 μm in diameter (∼ 7-day culture from freshly isolated cells). Prepare all the solutions and equipment before the experiment. Thaw Matrigel on ice.
Collect organoids into 15 mL tube containing 10 mL ice-cold PBS by pipetting the Matrigel layer containing organoids.
Mix and centrifuge at 500 × g for 5 min.

Digest the organoids with 0.05% Trypsin-EDTA (1 mL per well) for 5–10 min at 37°C. Gently pipette up and down in between.
Add 10 mL Basic medium II (see section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’) to stop digestion.
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 5 min.
Remove supernatant without disturbing the pellet and resuspend the cell pellet in 3 mL Basic medium II (see section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’) and do cell counting.
Depending on the different aims of the experiment, seed the cells using organoid culture medium (see section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’) at different cell densities. For passage the cells, seed 300,000 cells with 2 mL organoid medium per well for 6-well plates. For quantifying organoid-forming efficiency, seed 200–500 cells per well in 96-well plates.
Critical: All spins should be done in the refrigerated centrifuge at 4°C–8°C. Refresh the medium every 3–4 days.
Note: Organoid cultures from freshly isolated cells are usually ready for passage after 1 week. They can then be passaged every 4–6 days at a 1:4 ratio for expansion. The exact timing for passaging organoid cultures is determined by the growth rate of the organoids. We usually passage the culture when the majority of organoids are between 100–200 μm in diameter.
Note: Pipetting organoids after Trypsin treatment will result in a single-cell suspension. However, some cell clumps might still remain, which can be filtered out with a 40 μm cell strainer.
Making frozen stocks of MaSC/tumor organoids
Timing: 30 min
Prepare Freezing medium (see section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’) and cryovials before the experiment.
Dissociate the organoids into single cells based on steps 11–15.
Resuspend the cell pellet with 3 mL of Freezing medium (for the cell pellet from one well of 6-well plate).

Transfer 1 mL cell suspension into a cryogenic vial, place the vial into a slow-freezing container, and put it at −80°C freezer.
The following day, transfer the frozen cryovials to the liquid nitrogen tank for long-term storage.
Critical: All spins should be done in the refrigerated centrifuge at 4°C–8°C.
Processing MaSC/tumor organoids for histology
Timing: 4–7 days
Prepare 2% agarose: (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2])

(B) Coating the cryomold with 200 μL 2% low-melting agarose.

Mix 20 mg of low-melting agarose with 1 mL of water in a 2 mL tube, put the tube in a heat block set at 70°C to melt the agarose.
Let the agarose solution to cool down to about 45°C–50°C.
Skip step 23 for OCT frozen section preparation.
Collet the organoid in a 15 mL tube, add 10 mL ice-cold PBS to wash the organoids.
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 5 min and discard the supernatant.
Add 1 mL of 4% PFA or 10% formalin to fix the organoids for 30 min on ice.
Add 10 mL PBS to the tube and centrifuge at 500 × g for 5 min, discard the supernatant.
Repeat step 27 twice.
Resuspend the organoids in 1 mL 0.1% BSA/PBS and transfer them to a 1.5 mL tube.
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 5 min and discard the supernatant.
For paraffin-embedding sample preparation

Coat the bottom of a cryomold (10 × 10 × 5 mm) with a layer of 2% agarose by adding 100 μL per cryomold and spreading it with the pipette tip gently. Cool down the agarose at 22°C–25°C for 5 min.
Gently mix the organoids from step 30 with 100 μL of 2% agarose solution.
Critical: Cut off the end of a P200 pipette tip and use it to pipette the agarose. Bubbles need to be avoided during pipetting.
Gently place the organoids/agarose mixture into the agarose-coated cryomold using a cut P200 tip. Make sure to put the mixture in the middle of the cryomold.
Return the cryomold to the ice for 10–20 min until the gel is completely solidified.
Gently and carefully remove the solidified agarose containing the embedded organoids from the mold and transfer it into a tissue cassette for further processing.
Proceed with the paraffin embedding process following the standard FFPE embedding protocol.
Cut the section at 4–6 μm thickness using a microtome.
For OCT-embedding sample preparation
After step 30, add 1 mL 30% sucrose solution to the organoid pellet and place at 4°C overnight (12–16 h) to allow organoids to sink into sucrose solution.
Remove the sucrose as much as possible.
Place a few drops of OCT onto the center of the bottom of cryomold.
Add ∼300 μl (around 3 drops) of OCT to the organoid pellet. Gently mix and transfer the OCT/organoid mixture into the OCT drop in the cryomold using a cut 200 μL pipette tip.
Critical: Bubbles need to be avoided. If air bubbles occur in the tissue mold, remove them with a pipette tip.
Carefully drop more OCT onto the specimen until it is completely covered. Avoid any bubbles inside the OCT.

Snap freeze the block in liquid nitrogen. Frozen blocks could be stored at −80°C.
Cut 10 μm thick sections using a cryostat.
Immunofluorescence staining of MaSC/tumor organoids
Deparaffinization and rehydration for paraffin section: pass the tissue slides through the following steps (performed in fume hood):
100% Xylene I for 5 min
100% Xylene II for 5 min
Xylene/ethanol (1:1, v/v) for 5 min
100% ethanol for 5 min
95% ethanol for 5 min
75% ethanol for 5 min
50% ethanol for 5 min
Water for 5 min, twice.
Antigen retrieval: incubate slides in antigen unmasking buffer (citrate acid based) and perform antigen retrieval using retriever. The tissues will be processed automatically. In about 2–3 h, the slides will be cool down to 25°C. Wash the slides with water for 5 min twice.
Encircle the section with a hydrophobic barrier pen.
Blocking: incubate the section in blocking buffer (3% BSA, 0.1% TritonX-100 (optional) in PBS) for 1 h at 22°C–25°C.
Primary antibody incubation: discard blocking buffer, incubate the section in diluted primary antibody in 3% BSA of PBS overnight (12–16 h) at 4°C in the dark.
Wash with 0.1% Tween-20/PBS for 5 min, 3 times with shaking.
Secondary antibody incubation: Incubate the sections in fluorescent-dye conjugated secondary antibody diluted in 3% BSA of PBS for 1 h at 22°C–25°C in the dark.
Wash the slides with 0.1% Tween-20/PBS for 5 min, 3 times with shaking
Mount coverslip with the mounting medium (with DAPI).
Capture images under confocal microscopy.
Critical: Antigen retrieval buffer should be optimal based on different antibodies.
Genetic engineering in organoids
Timing: around 3 weeks
Production of Lentivirus:
Day 1: HEK293T cells preparation.
Coat 10 cm plates with 20 μg/mL collagen I in PBS for 1 h at 22°C–25°C.

Split HEK293T cells 1:4 from 90% confluent culture to the collagen I-coated plates using Transfection medium (see section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’).

Add transfection mixture to cells.
Re-fresh transfection medium (see section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’) after 4–5 h.
Day 3: Re-fresh transfection medium (10 mL per 10 cm plate).
Critical: Add new medium dropwise onto cells to avoid dislodging the cells.
Day 4: Collect viral supernatant in a 50 mL tube and add fresh transfection medium.
Day5: Repeat step d.
Day 6: Collect viral supernatant again. Filter through a 0.45 μm filter. Aliquot and freeze at −80°C for long-term storage if the virus is not used within 1 week.
Critical: Virus can be concentrated with Lenti-X Concentrator (Takara, Cat # 631232) or other methods to achieve higher titer.
Lentiviral infection of organoids
Day 1: Prepare single cells as section ‘Passaging MaSC/tumor organoid culture’. For viral transduction in 6-well, resuspend 300,000 cells with 1 mL virus-containing medium (organoid culture medium containing 5% Matrigel, see section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’.) with 5 μg/mL polybrene.
Critical: The virus dilution ratio should be adjusted based on the viral titer.
Day 2: Refresh organoid culture medium after overnight (12–16 h) infection.
Day 3: Refresh organoid culture medium and supplement with a selection antibiotic (e.g., 2 μg/mL puromycin). Transduced cells can be FACS sorted if using fluorescent marker-containing vectors.
Critical: The dosage of puromycin may need to be optimized for different cells.
